videos.title: Grassroots Gravel 2024 course preview-a fall event in Pueblo, Colorado
videos.description:
Grassroots Gravel is Oct 12 in Pueblo, Colorado, with four distances ranging from a beginner-friendly 14 miles to a challenging and beautiful 110-mile adventure.

Learn more and register at https://www.grassrootsgravel.com/

--
Thanks to Josh Bernales for the edit.
-
Gear I use for shooting (not sponsored!):
Hover X1 Self-Flying Drone: https://amzn.to/3V7MUn5
DJI Mini 3 Drone: https://amzn.to/3wK4eVY
GoPro Hero Black 11: https://amzn.to/3wK4eVY
DJI Action Cam 4: https://amzn.to/3wK4eVY
DJI Pocket Osmo 3: https://amzn.to/3wK4eVY
Sony Alpha ZV-E10: https://amzn.to/3QUSqHf
Sony Alpha a6300: https://amzn.to/3K7jFKK
Sony E 50mm F1.8 OSS lens: https://amzn.to/3QNGh6L

--
The Ride is supported in 2024 by:
Castelli clothing: http://tinyurl.com/43k6pftp
Perc Coffee: https://tinyurl.com/etzyekwr (save 15% with code 'ride15')
Giro helmets: http://tinyurl.com/72svzzxp
Silca maintenance: https://bit.ly/47xxvzj (save 10% with code 'theride')
First Endurance nutrition: https://bit.ly/41SDgqq (save 20% with code 'THERIDE')
Shimano shoes & glasses: http://tinyurl.com/ye274tep
Feedback Sports stands & tools: https://bit.ly/3S9Dq8r
videos.transcript:
Grassroots gravel in Southern Colorado
has something for everyone whether
you're looking to do your first ever
gravel event or really challenge
yourself against some Stout competitors
and some steep climbs today I'm out here
riding the course with race director
Adam Davidson and some friends and we're
going to show you all the good times and
beautiful scenery you are in for if you
come down to pelo Colorado for the race
on October 12
in this video we're going to walk you
through the different courses the
surfaces some Tire recommendations and
what you can look forward to when you
come to race Grassroots gravel in P
Colorado on October 12th and yes I'm
Runing the brand new 13-speed Shram AIS
Explorer gravel group you can find all
the details and my opinions about that
in the link above but as pertains to
this course I very much appreciated
having the wide range cassette the
1046 with a 4 to chain ring point is if
you're doing the long course you're
going to appreciate having some low low
gears that 12 mile climb goes on for
indeed many miles and you're climbing
more than 3,000 ft on that one climb
alone so when the climb heads over
double digits I appreciate having low
gears while many events lean into the
pro side of racing that is not the focus
of Grassroots grabble of course fast
people are welcome here but the main
thrust of the event is everyday folks
whether you're from peblo or anywhere
else around the country or the world if
you have a bike want to challenge
yourself on
gravel Adam and his crew are happy to
welcome you to the roads around peblo
the courses at Grassroots gravel um
we've got a 15 a 40 a 75 and 110 which
actually we are standing at the summit
of the course right now and the 15 and
40 are are both out and back rolling
courses that uh are actually one of my
favorite local rides it's what we ride
every single week in the red Creek rally
and they're uh it's a slow climb uh on
kind of what we're looking at right here
you know there's no crazy technical
gravel on any of that on any of our
courses for that matter and
uh yeah the 15 turns around at the top
of red Creek Springs which is our weekly
classic warm-up and then the 40 turns
around at Red creek volunteer fire and
rescue the 15mi course is the start of
our weekly ride and last year you know
we had a whole spectrum of folks riding
that thing from people that were just
looking for fewer miles to uh folks
riding with their kids we had people all
the way down to uh 10 I'm almost certain
riding the 15 uh with their dad which
was U you know really cool to see that
energy out there with folks just having
a good time and also pushing through you
know as uh as we all find our challenge
out in the course and so uh yeah that
was really neat to see and something
that I feel comfortable saying the 15 is
a approachable challenge for every level
and age um that is comfortable riding on
some dirt our 75 mile course that one uh
uses the same the same route as the 15
and the 40 but keeps going and comes and
drops down into the Bula Valley and
that's the point where the air cools
down you're surrounded by ponderosas and
you can smell them and you could just do
a quick dip into the valley and then
climb back out and then roll back into
town on burntmill road and that is fast
rollers uh across some of the you're
going to pass some of the oldest ranches
in Colorado right there which I think is
really cool
the 75m route and the 110 for that
matter finish through stem Beach which
is a natural area that's owned by evz
Rocky Mountain steel and they are
partnering with us to provide access to
that for this one day only of the year
otherwise you cannot go through there
it's this gorgeous Gravel Road that
you've got a straight away between two
big ponds and the Finish flags are right
at the end of that and that's the timing
finish and so once you know you have
your Sprint against your best bud or
your new buds or your biggest competitor
you then get to relax and cruise back
into town to downtown in fuel and iron
the 110 M course also known as the hole
and if anyone is
wondering what is the deal with the half
and the whole for the two longer courses
weblo Colorado has this uh very Hefty
delicacy known as a slopper which is a
big old
cheeseburger with peblo green chili
poured on top of it usually served in a
bowl and when you go to a place they'll
usually ask you like do you want the
half or do you want the whole there's
there's a bunch of them and I won't get
into the debate on who who is the
slopper place but if you were to go
somewhere and order a half and you know
a pint of Coors or something they will
know what you're talking about and and
so that's that's uh that's the that's
why it's the half in the hole the 110
the whole
slopper that is the uh it's it's one of
my favorite routes to ride period
because you get a full sampling of this
region you know you're starting downtown
so you get to see pbl's Historic
downtown you're riding through the high
desert Past Lake Pueblo State Park and
then you come up into the Bula Valley
and the wet mountains and you get to do
what is one of my favorite segments ever
which is 12 M and 12 Mile which is where
we're standing right now at the Summit
is a 3,400 ft climb and 11 1/2 miles and
it is beautiful and it it it will
constantly remind you that it is 3,400
ft of climbing and uh I love it because
the the gravel itself is never too
technical but the hill itself and the
the grade is constantly varied through
the whole thing so like you feel like
you're done and then you're not or you
feel like you're getting a break and
maybe you do but you never really know
unless you know this hill really well
and even on our course preview today I
could have sworn that the spot that we
were meeting up was just around the
corner and I was
wrong so uh you know once you get here
to the summit um you still have about a
mile mile and a half of just pure
descent down to Highway 165 and at that
point you are home free for a minute or
at least you get a breather and um after
riding 165 for a second you're going to
drop on to Old San Isabel road which is
a kind of more intimate a little bit
tighter cornered the trees create a
little bit more of a tunnel than 12 Mile
and I love it for that because it's like
a different flavor it's almost like a
more uh
rustic Gravel Road even though again the
gravel's Never Too chunky
it's when you're going to get some shade
and it's also where the folks that like
to descend uh and and you know are able
to stay responsible in the
corners can can differentiate themselves
from other Riders uh that being said the
race will probably be one on 12 Mile in
my opinion descending descending Old St
Isabel road is a treat because it's
really tight and and the Aspens are
right there up over for you and uh it's
really winding and so it's a fun descent
after you finish the old s Isabel
descent you're going to hit an aid
station it's probably going to be right
when you want it because you will have
just climbed 12 Mile and done A rad
descent and you're ready for a snack and
after that you are now kind of just
entering the world of rolling smooth and
fast gravel uh with the the wet
mountains as your backdrop and a whole
bunch of historic ranches surrounding
you the 110 finishes uh on the same roof
as the 75 finish so you're going to be
going past uh you know agricultural land
and um coming through the stem Beach
Natural Area and again that one has one
of my favorite finishes and I really
pushed to get us that partnership with
evz Rocky Mountain steel because it is
just this awesome tenth of a mile razor
straight gravel Causeway between these
two ponds and the Finish flags are there
and then you you your timing stops
hopefully at A rad Sprint and then you
Cruise back into town to fuel and
[Music]
iron this course in particular is
especially fat fast the gravel is very
Compact and rolls really well you can
get away with almost any tire out there
even a large Road tire which is a lot of
fun um you go a lot faster on the
descents the bigger tire you run and you
go a lot faster on the climbs the
smaller Tire you run and so you kind of
get to pick your poison I'm a pretty big
fan of the 40 semi slick in almost all
conditions and that's basically what I
have on all my bikes the cool thing
about Southern Colorado is we get this
really great mix of high desert mix with
alpine and so we get a little more of an
aid climate that you you see around um
Boulder and Denver um you get really
this kind of feel similar to parts of
Northern New Mexico we get cactus mixed
with um Aspen which is really special we
get a really great mixture of animals I
would be very surprised if you didn't
see um Pronghorn or analou out here as
well as some really large jack rabbits
and I don't know I love all of my little
animal friends that I see out on the
Prairies when I'm riding in this part of
Colorado I I will be riding and
exhibiting I think last year I did the
40 mile and attempted to do it as fast
as possible to race back and set up a
booth and I think I'm going to do
exactly the same thing this year is try
to do the 40 mile a little bit faster
and race back and set up a booth again
how did the racing play out last year
you got the win congrats on that how' it
go thanks yeah it went great um the
racing was pretty quick the gravel here
is very fast the group uh broke off
around mile 20 just three of us and then
it broke off to just two of us Michael
caner and I a local Rider from Fort
Collins and we battled up 12 mile
together pretty much the whole way I
could see him the whole way and then we
rode
solo mono Mano all the way back to peblo
it's a long way back it's a long way
back it was a it was a very long uh
individual time trial back to peblo but
it was lovely I could just get in my
zone and enjoy the course so for people
looking for a fast time what would you
recommend and terms of tires or Wheels
yeah I think uh in Broad Strokes you
know yeah a slick Tire would be good but
uh ride whatever you feel comfortable
but slicks I would
recommend honestly a 40 or 42 just
because there are some washboard on the
course and you just want to stay focused
on uh staying safe but I think a 40 and
a 42 slick would be perfect I'm going to
I will run like a 42 42 Pathfinder and
one final question your honor what's
what's the postrace meal of
choice postrace meal of choice is
probably some uh over here in Southern
Colorado so probably some something to
do with uh green chili you know and I
also need a couple beers after the race
you know welld deserved beers after the
race you'll be able to find both of
those quite easily yeah I think so I
think so all right thanks thanks for
riding today yeah thank you awes so how
did you Lauren how did you get into
riding gravel bikes um well I kind of
got into it um with the Grassroots
gravel the red Creek rally ride I bought
a gravel bike and went on the rides and
just loved it I loved the less traffic I
loved being able to ride in the
mountains um the community of gravel is
just wonderful and um in Pablo and uh
with Grassroots they've created such a
wonderful Community here where it's very
welcoming to all types of writers and so
uh it's just kind of flourished from
there what would you say to folks who
interested but maybe a little
intimidated about the surface or the
distance man this is such a welcoming
Community say like know your body know
your bike but push yourself what a great
place to push yourself is is this event
because it's very supportive the aid
stations were wonderful everyone was so
kind and uplifting and um you know you
try something new you're always
surprised about what you can accomplish
for sure and then where are we now what
what's the backdrop what is this what's
behind us okay we're at Lake San Isabel
which is a beautiful spot here in uh Ry
Colorado this like spot is like very
kind of special to me um I grew up like
fishing hiking camping this area and so
to be able to like ride my gravel bike I
mean like that's incredible coming down
um the highway here I was like looking
at all the wild flowers and seeing like
it's just so amazing to get to recreate
in the Southern Colorado Mountains for
sure
n
but of course you don't need the latest
and greatest to do this event or any
other as long as you've got a bike in
good working order and a helmet on your
head you are good to go and yes having
wider gravel tires set it a lower softer
pressure will feel good and I think
having lower gears to help you up the
Steep climbs will o help but really any
bike is fine and if you have to get off
and walk get off and walk I appreciate
looking at the names and results in ages
of the events from last year where I was
seeing everything from kids younger than
teenagers all the way up to a gentleman
in his 70s out here getting after it
when I got into town yesterday afternoon
I enjoyed cruising around a bit on the
bike going through City Park popping
down to the river trail a lot of
families out there enjoying the water on
all sorts of craft after we wrap up here
I'm going to head over to fuel and iron
Food Hall check out some of the options
there top off before hit the road
Grassroots gravel down here in peblo
Colorado the day before the event
there's a few ShakeOut rides we got
Marlin bonky from all bodies on bikes
leading ride we've got Eric from
Albuquerque my hometown leading a pedal
homies community dad ride hope to see
you guys down here for Grassroots gravel
October 12th in PUO Colorado

videos.title: A Gravel Race For EVERYONE! Grassroots Gravel
videos.description:
I definitely wasn't ready for this volume... but still wanted to ride the gravel roads Pueblo has to offer. 

See how I managed in this video! 

Check out more about this event here: 
https://www.grassrootsgravel.com/

-JRP


DISCLAIMER: Below is a list of what I use to make these videos and what I use on Most of my bike rides. If you purchase something through the links below it will give me a small commision at no extra cost of the original product to you. By doing this you are helping the channel out so if you choose to do so, thank you in advance. 

Cameras I Use
-Main Camera: https://amzn.to/38inxDl
-Favorite Lens: https://amzn.to/32PJGYx
-Amazing Prime Lens: https://amzn.to/38qPGIN

videos.title: 2024 Grassroots Gravel "The Half" 75 Miler
videos.description: Experimenting with overlays, they definitely aren't always accurate, especially on the speed one. I'll work on improving my stills there!

videos.title: The race for everyone: Grassroots Gravel 2025 recap
videos.description:
Grassroots Gravel is a race for everyone. An invitation into cycling. A celebration of community connection and the joy of riding bikes together. Grown in Pueblo. Powered by UCHealth. @UniversityofColoradoHealth 

More folks than ever joined us in Pueblo, Colorado for our third year. 1,200 registrants, nearly 40 exhibitors, and a concert featuring Los Mocochetes and The Savage Blush made the weekend vibrate with energy. Huge thanks to every person who volunteered, rode, supported, and believed in Grassroots Gravel. 

Special shout out to UCHealth for supporting a healthy Colorado and the Grassroots Gravel experience, to our Friday Social Ride lead and sweep crew from the Ride for Racial Justice and Adaptive Adventures for welcoming so many into cycling and to Pueblo on race weekend, to T-Fiber for making the phenomenal concert possible, to SoCO Student Media for incredible stage production and sound, and to Visit Pueblo for believing in this vision. This experience takes all of us.

Learn more + join us next year:
https://www.grassrootsgravel.com

Connect with partners:
UCHealth: https://www.uchealth.org
Visit Pueblo: https://visitpueblo.org/ 
T-Fiber: https://fiber.t-mobile.com/pueblo?utm_source=marketing_flyer&utm_medium=qr&utm_campaign=grassroots_gravel
SoCO Student Media: https://socostudentmedia.com/ 
Ride for Racial Justice: https://rideforracialjustice.com 
Adaptive Adventures: https://adaptiveadventures.org

Shot by:
@JRODVISUALS 
@jollymuleproductions  
@untitledmedia 

Edited by:
 ⁨@JRODVISUALS

what we rode together. Sam's a lot

videos.title: My First Ever Gravel Race Was HARD | Grassroots Gravel
videos.description:
My first gravel race started as a road trip from Oregon to Colorado and ended with a 19-mile PR and memories that’ll last a lifetime. No day goes exactly as planned, but that’s the beauty of it.

From unexpected detours to that final push across the finish line, this ride reminded me why I fell in love with cycling in the first place. Here’s to grit, laughter, and the moments you never see coming.

⛰ Let’s connect and explore together:
Website: https://gabriellamingrone.com

Instagram: @gabriellamingrone

TikTok: @gabriellamingrone

See you in the next one!
videos.transcript:
It's just weird.
>> It's a tough situation.
>> Yeah.
>> Welcome back to my channel, everyone.
For the past 2 months, I have been
training for my first gravel race, and
all that work has led to this moment.
It's officially race week. And tomorrow,
I start my drive to Colorado for
grassroots gravel. I currently live in
southern Oregon, so that's going to be
quite the haul. I figured I'd go ahead
and show you what I'm packing and got
quite a few things going on. So, let's
get into that. I thought it'd be fun to
kind of go through what I'm packing for
cycling. All right, so as far as gear
goes, here is everything that I'm
packing. I've got two different pattern
jerseys. I'm still deciding which one to
wear because I'm not entirely sure what
the weather is going to be like in
Pueblo. If it's too hot, I definitely
won't be wearing the black. So, I'll go
with this pattern. But it's honestly
dependent on the weather once we get
there. And then I also have two
different bibs to choose from. Same
thing. If it's a little bit hotter, I'll
be wearing the cargo bib because it's a
little bit lighter. Otherwise, I'll be
wearing the matching jersey and bib
combo. I'll be bringing this windbreaker
from Goreware as well. Since it's been
so cold in southern Oregon, I've been
using this really frequently. It might
be so hot in PBLO. I have no idea. So,
I'm just going to have it in my bag just
in case. Last but not least are these
Pearly Zoomi cycling shoes. I've only
been training with them for about a week
and a half, but I love them. So, I'm
going to go ahead and leave the Alt at
home and take these with me. So, that's
it for clothes. Let me go ahead and pack
these up and then I'll show you some of
the smaller essentials I'm bringing with
me. Okay, so right here are just a few
things that I'll be bringing. These are
my essentials for my race kit. Some bone
conducting headphones. We've got our
Zeal Optics sunglasses. Of course, we
have our Smith helmet, my Apple Watch,
and hoping that it doesn't die on me
this time because it always tends to do
that. And then these are actually a new
addition to my kit. These are Cliff's
blocks. These are energy chews. This one
is black cherry, but it's got caffeine
in it. And this is salted watermelon.
It's better for sodium and hydration.
And then I've got my racing gloves. And
the latest addition is my Insta 360.
This will come in super handy while I'm
actually out riding, so it'll hopefully
be able to help me capture part of the
race. So, I'm really excited for that
one. And of course, my water bladder is
probably one of the most important
things. This is by USA, and I use it on
every single ride. And yeah, so this is
the full race kit. I'm excited to
actually put everything to use.
You know, I am super excited that it's
finally race week, but I won't lie, I'm
pretty nervous. I'm mostly anxious
because this is something I've never
done before. Typically, people who know
me know that I am a very riskadverse
person. So to be going to a gravel race
where I've never been to PBlo, Colorado.
I've never ridden on Colorado gravel
because I know it's very different from
southern Oregon gravel roads. And of
course to be contending with elevation
that's a little bit higher than in
southern Oregon. Definitely put myself
in one of the most unique race
situations I could have for my first
one. All of this, by the way, is stuff
that I completely knew when I first
signed up for this race. But honestly,
for the first time, I really wanted to
take a risk and to dive into the unknown
because I knew that this would be
something that would push me past my
limits and honestly show me what I can
do when I push beyond my comfort zone.
After these past few weeks, I've learned
that I actually approach fear in a very
different way where I used to avoid fear
completely. Now, it's kind of like I
feel the fear and I know that I'm going
to do it anyway. So, really what I'm
trying to say is I'm not someone who's
just suddenly not scared anymore. I know
that if I let fear hold me back from
uncomfortable situations, I will never
get the reward for all of this hard
training. And that to me would be an
absolute shame to let fear just get in
the way of any progress I could make.
All right, with that said, I need to put
up the camera because I need to pack up
my car. So, I will see you from the road
bright and early in the morning.
Got the skybox over there.
We've got the bike rack and the bike
over here. Ruby is working on a plan and
we are stuck here at this gas station in
Utah. Oh, it's a tough situation.
>> So sorry, but
>> it's just it's just the bars at this
point. Good girl, baby. Good girl. I
know. We're coming.
>> She's a queen.
>> Okay.
>> We're going to we're going to put these
down a little bit better.
>> Actually, not bad.
>> Not bad. I think that's the best we can
do right now. Let's put on the
>> You're crushing it, Rubs.
>> I'm sorry.
We're about to take off again. See how
this works.
>> You want to try it?
>> Let's do it.
All right.
She's holding.
I think she's holding. Okay.
Heat.
First time in PBO, Colorado. So, had to
get a shakeout ride in before the race.
We got Ruby
following. He's got the doggos.
All right, we're going to get moving
again. Let's get after it.
Definitely feeling tight from all the
driving, but honestly, I'm surprised
that I feel as good as I do right now.
It's getting late and I want to get a
good night's sleep. So, I think I'm
going to go ahead and call it early. All
right, 3 miles. Not bad.
Good morning from Colorado. It is
officially race day and the sky is
absolutely blowing up behind me. It's so
beautiful. Don't mind my puffy face. It
is early this morning. We are packing up
and about to have some breakfast and
then we're going to hit the road and get
to the expo center. Nerves are high, but
we're pushing through. Taking a deep
breath today. Let's get it.
>> Hey.
>> Hey, pop.
>> Hey, I'm hiding. So,
>> you're riding right now?
>> Yeah, I'm riding.
>> Sorry.
>> Oh my god.
Hey, I just wanted to say uh you're
going to do great today, so don't worry
about anything. It's just, you know,
little pointers. You know, you're going
to race, hold yourself back in the
beginning and then take off.
And if you're going to just ride the
race, find yourself.
>> Okay. Bye, Dad.
>> Bye.
You're here to race and push yourself,
but you're also here to have fun. I hope
some flavor of that. So, let's make sure
that we are being respectful of our
other riders. We're being respectful of
our other motorists. And like
>> if you are standing up for the Chili or
the mile.
>> All these bike riders.
>> Go have fun.
After leaving town and riding about 3
miles on the road, I had finally reached
the point where the pavement turned to
gravel.
And then the real race began.
Mentally, that climb felt brutal. Heart
pumping hard, legs tight. My body was
not where I needed it to be. My energy
quickly depleted once the adrenaline
wore off, and I felt the lack of
calories set in.
>> My goal quickly became make it to the
first aid station and recover.
Let's go.
>> My lesson here, hydration and calories
make all the difference in mood.
>> Let's go.
>> Definitely hungry.
>> Oh my god, my anxiety is gone now. I'm
like,
>> I left that aid station in high spirits.
Stoked.
Woo. That was a great stop.
Feeling fueled up now. Feeling good.
Ruby and the dogs stopped to say hello.
I actually just made my whole day. That
was amazing. I feel so stoked right now.
Holy God damn. My gosh. I don't
even know what I'm doing right now.
I'm a racist. Oh my god.
After that refuel, I fell into a groove
and started feeling my training kick in.
Chipping away at miles and my confidence
grew.
Feeling great.
Sometimes you got to give yourself a
little pep talk. You know, no one's
going to do it for you
when you're out here by yourself.
Got to keep that hype going.
Perfect.
Eventually, I cruised to double digits
and suddenly felt like my goal was in
reach.
Heat. Heat.
Oh
my gosh.
Hi.
>> That is so cool, guys.
>> It was It was incredible.
>> I'm glad. I'm so happy for you.
>> Thanks, Pop. Oh my gosh. First gravel
race in the books. Feeling so stoked
right now. I finished two hours on the
dot, 19.7 miles, which is my longest
ride.
I mean, I I beat all of my PRs. Feeling
so incredibly blessed right now. hanging
with Ruby and hanging with the dogs. I'm
gonna go get some food because I need
it. I'm feeling so so stoked and so high
in life right now. That was incredible.
Shout out to Grassroots Gravel. You guys
put on a great race. Absolutely awesome.
The stoke was so high the whole time.
Energy was impeccable.
Could not want anything more than this.
So awesome. Guys, thanks for following
along. It's been an amazing ride.
